comments.commentBody: My 15 year old daughter is a big fan of Derpie, the character in the "My Little Pony" cartoon. As it turns out, the cartoon, which was originally aimed at little kids, has quite a following among teens and older adults. Derpie is a clumsy blonde pony.
Get over your Obama obsession and find something intelligent to write.

The Feds need to seize the county, put Obama statues in every neighborhood, force the residents to pay obeisance on a daily basis, and make those responsible pay with the supreme penalty, singing John Brown's Body in Yiddish.

Vengeance in mine, sayeth the Lord.

"He even ignores his OWN red lines"

Red lines just define for neocons what lies to tell, what lies will get them what they want.

I grew up in and around NYC although my wife did not and my kids have not. Ironically, as the Times has requested advice for travelling to the city with kids, I have been planning our latest trip (which will occur next week). On the outset, I would recommend to the Times that they include options for a variety of ages (from babies to teens).

My first piece of advice to families is that they conduct a little (or a lot of) research before setting foot in the city. New York, in addition to being on a mammoth scale as far as the number of options for everything, is always changing. Consider how many attractions (as well as restaurants, subway stations, etc.) were impacted by Superstorm Sandy alone. For example, we are not able to visit the Statue of Liberty next week because it still hasn't reopened. But places open and close even without the effects of weather. So PLAN AHEAD to avoid surprises, or worse with children, disappointment.

I would also recommend buying tickets in advance for attractions, especially if, say, purchasing online does not require stating a specific time and date to visit. We have visited the American Museum of Natural History twice with our kids, and both times failed to buy in advance. This meant long waits in line -- an event that children of any age don't need to endure. I recognize that changes in travel plans could prove costly if you have bought ahead, but it's worth considering. Despite the wait, our children loved the museum!

"In a purpose built deep fryer they fall below the heating element into a cool zone."

There's no "cool zone" under the heating elements in a deep fryer. The oil closest to the heating elements is the hottest, and the breading crumbs etc that fall to the bottom (close to the elements) continue to burn as long as the fryer is on, slowly and inevitably compromising the oils flavor.

Which is why a "decent' restaurant filters their oil nightly, and the chef smells it and decides to use it again... or to toss it.

(Former execitive chef who worked in a high end seafood joint with a fryer bank of 6 fryers.)

"There is only one way to "grill" -- charcoal."

Bull.

Grilling requires a heat source from below that is directed upwards to a metal cooking surface above. It doesn'r matter if that heat source is charcoal, wood, heated stones, or propane/gas. There are even 'electric' grills, which are efficient in their own manner.

As a former executive chef... I've done it all, literally. It's all good, but there are some differences that are profound. Gas grilling can be easily controled with the turn of a knob, in addition to raising or lowering the cooking surface.

Charcoal cooking is great, but the same level of control isn't there at a touch, except for lowering or raising the cooking surface... if thats even possible, which it isn't on many charcoal grills.

When my friends and associates ask me for advice on what kind of "grill" to buy, I always recommend propane.

"stupid law?"
Then change it, 'Jersey.

This paper should really highlight why there's a stupid law that prevents you from having a primary if the special election is held on the Nov. general election date; the options are have one election in Nov. with no primary, or three election days (a primary and two generals for the Senate and Gov.) to have a primary.
No, it is an even bigger waste of money

"What am I missing here?" Apples and oranges.

Blago's efforts would line his own pockets, Christie's efforts would not.

Whether it picks the pockets of NJ taxpayers is irrelevant. As Governor, he is legally entitled to call this election.

Blago was not legally entitled to line his own pockets, despite the sorry Illinois track record of' gubernatorial corruption..
Gov. Christie is following the Constitution. Gov. Blagojevich violated the Constitution. Yes, you are missing something here!
The fact you are missing is that it is legal.

Let me get this straight: Gov. Rod Blagojevich went to jail for attempting to personally profit from the sale of Obama's open Senate seat. Yet  Gov. Christie spends $25 million of taxpayer money on a special election in order to protect his own political position in a move that profits only himself, and which may someday help put him in the White House, and somehow this is all considered to be perfectly legal.  What am I missing here?

Republicans just can't get their story straight. When a Democrat or a Democratic president spends money for the benefit of the middle class and the good of society as a whole it's a crime against humanity and an abuse of power, but when a Republican openly squandersmoney to further his personal agenda it's laudable.

And a Republican who blatantly says "I don't know what the cost is and I frankly don’t care" to boot. He didn’t even take the cost into account? This exposes how little Republicans really care about taxpayers' money. They always expose their hypocrisy and double standards. They can't seem to help it.
Yet another example of a politician choosing an electorate instead of allowing an electorate to chose the politician.

That word, derpy, is a hit! It is a great word.

What was the post about? The links?

The only thing I can remember is derpy.

Derpy, derpy, derpy!

Nice idea, but unfortunately we've sunk to the level that the appointee is there not to "represent the interests of the state" but to represent the agenda of one party or the other, or the agenda of the president.  Any benefit to the "people" is secondary.  Pretty sad.

I don't know. Seems like the governor is shrinking from his duties to me.  Why not just appoint someone whom he feels is qualified and would represent the interests of the state in the Senate ( republican, democrat or independent)  until a legit election could be held in 2014? not a slapped together mini election at the end of summer.  Save the state money and election overload.
The would be the GOP, they've set records for filibusters ever since they lost the Senate in 2006.

Note that you have to focus on a single instance, and ignore the records set by the GOP in the Senate since 2006. As to the recess appointment rulings, there is no requirement for him to "denounce" anything since SCOTUS may hear this issue and make a final disposition and the opinions are only binding in the relevant circuits, not nationwide.

Incidentally, during the final three years of the Bush presidency, there was only ONE vacancy that occurred, so your statement that there were a plural number of appointments by Bush is simply inaccurate. The other two seats in question only became vacant in 2011 and 2013.
You do not sound like a moderate at all.
Wouldn't be good fun if the President nominated Sandra Day O'Connor for one of the open court seats?  Then sit back and see what Cruz, etal, would do! haha

The minority in the senate represents less than a third of the people of the nation. unfit mitt may have gotten 47% of the vote (irony of ironies) but that does not pertain to the senate partisan distribution. The 2 pr state rule allows for a tiny fraction of the nation to have disproportionate representation. That may part of the design, but it was never the intent that a tiny fraction of the nation would so overwhelmingly stop democracy from functioning on all levels at all times.
Your comments mirror my own which I've written about in these pages. Well said!

Buddy, that''s one trip, and you're only considering a family of four, it's not a good comparison, if you look in cabs, most cab rides have 1 or 2 persons. Put a few trips and the bike is cheaper.
Not to mention the health effects.

A question: can two people share an annual membership? I mean , obviously they can't check out bikes at the same time, but ...just to have a quick ride now and then, it might be worth it to share the enrollment fee.

I used to own a bike in NYC. But the traffic was too crazy most days , the roads too pot holed, (in Soho, the cobblestones too bumpy), for me to feel safe, even with a helmet, so I would ride only on Sundays, a quieter day. Frankly, biking in European cities is easier. New Yorkers in these comments may put up a tough front, and mock the author's caution, but NYC is a free for all, favoring vehicles like taxis, buses and private cars . Let's thank former mayor Guiliani for that--- reinforcing drivers 'sense of entitlement.
it's absurdly overpriced.  Shame on citibank and DOT.
He vas mayor of istanbul not ankara.

The Turkish Prime Minister is a very corrupt, dangerous and arrogant man, with strong dictatorial tendencies.

Corrupt:

There are currently eight indictments for corription against him from the time he was the mayor of Ankara. The reason the cases have stalled is because he has immunity from prosecution as prime minister.

Secondly, he became a very wealthy man during his mayorship. He does not deny this. His explanation was that he received many fine gifts when his son got married. Tranlation: If you want to bribe the mayor, just wait for some excuse/event to happen like a wedding and use it as a pretext to bribe him.

Dangerous:

A few years back, he launched a ship filled with terrorists from the IHH organization to run the legal Israeli blockade of Gaza. When the israelis boarded the ship to check for weapons, they were attacked with knives and iron bars. Nine terrorists were killed.

Arrogant:

As the riots in his country swelled and spread throughout the country (with two dead), he flew off for a tour of Africa and other places for a couple of weeks. He's also referred to the peaceful and unarmed demonstrators as "bums."

Dictatorial:

He is currently working very hard to have the courts vest far more power in the office of prime minister.

thecamelshumpblog.com
And his sister, no doubt, is named Belle?

I was a Jennifer (top name for 15+ years) and hated it. Jennifer, Jen, Jenny, Jennie... oh please, just call me something else! When I got married, I changed both my first and last names. Though that unusual choice has caused some confusion, I am happy to "officially" have the first name I've been using as a nickname since age 18.
